4.text: Did Jethro give Moses bad advice?

177.text:
Now, the question is: Did Jethro give Moses
good advice? For many, it is clear that he

183.text:
did, for several reasons. First, Moses could
not possibly handle every matter. He did not

189.text:
have the time or the energy. Second, sharing
power is always a good idea. Third, Jewish

196.text:
law says one should never judge alone. The
Midrash says:

200.text:
May a Jew who has been appointed rabbi or
judge of the community administer justice

205.text:
alone? Our rabbis have learned: Do not judge
alone, for there is only One who judges alone,

212.text:
[God]. [Deuteronomy R. 1:10]
Major commentaries approve. The Mechilta says:

219.text:
Jethro had seven names. One of then was “Yeter”,
meaning “added”. Because of the good advice

225.text:
he gave Moses on delegating authority, an
extra portion was added to the Torah [Mechilta,

231.text:
Some will say, however, that this was a unique
case, to which unique rules apply, and argue

238.text:
that Jethro gave Moses bad advice, for several
reasons. First, Moses did not consult God

245.text:
for advice, just Jethro. If God wanted Moses
to do less work, He would have given him a

251.text:
way. God was clearly in charge, even of the
details. Jethro himself tells Moses to heed

257.text:
his advice “if God commands you so”, but
God never does.

263.text:
Second, Moses asks only the people, not God,
if they agree with Jethro’s plan. Why did

271.text:
the people accept? The Sifri says their reason
was devious: They felt they could bribe or

277.text:
sway an ordinary judge, but not Moses:
The people decided the matter for their benefit.

284.text:
.. They were saying [to themselves], “Many
judges will now be appointed over us. If one

289.text:
does not know us, we shall bring him a gift,
and he will show us favor.” [Sifri (Midrash),

297.text:
A third reason is that it was the wrong time.
The idea of training people to take over after

302.text:
Moses was gone was sound, but the people wanted
a full judiciary system installed right away,

310.text:
A fourth reason is that Jethro was an idolater
at the time, an outsider, although he later

317.text:
converted to Judaism. This raises the question:
Should advice be accepted no matter what the

326.text:
A fifth reason is that all the laws were new.
Only Moses properly understood them, through

332.text:
the Oral Law. In the entire voluminous Written
and Oral laws God gave to Moses (later), there

339.text: was nothing about Moses delegating authority.

342.text:
A sixth reason is that delegating authority
may have gone against Moses’ personal inclination.

350.text:
After all, he did not think of it himself,
even though one would think it should be obvious.

355.text:
A seventh reason is: What are the “great”
matters that would be left for Moses to decide,

362.text:
and the “small” matters that would be
left to the judges? There is no answer. Judges

368.text:
would be tempted to improvise, to leave their
mark, rather than defer to Moses. Also, different

374.text: judges may give different answers to a question.

378.text:
The eighth reason is perhaps the most important.
Delegating authority prevented people direct

387.text:
access to the greatest prophet in Israel,
Moses; an encounter they would remember their

392.text:
entire life and act accordingly. The Sifri
says:

396.text:
The people should have told Moses: "Moses,
our teacher, from whom is it better to learn,

401.text:
from you or from your student? Isn't it better
to learn from you?" [Sifri (Midrash), also

406.text:
quoted by Rashi]
The Sfat Emet, 19th-century Hassidic rabbi,

411.text:
echoes those sentiments, saying:
Would the people have responded to the report

416.text:
of the spies with such bitter tears had they
not been insulated from the teaching and training

421.text:
of Moses?... The result was a stunted spiritual
growth.

426.text:
Contemporary rabbi Sherman adds that accepting
[Jethro's] proposal was:

431.text:
…one of those unintentional sins that would
bear poisoned fruit for thousands of years

437.text:

440.text:
Indeed, many people have reported that their
lives were changed by a brief encounter with

444.text:
a great sage. The last Lubavitcher Rebbe comes
to mind. Also, in the Jewish tradition, God

452.text:
wants Jews to address Him directly, not through
a hierarchy of priests and judges.

458.text:
Commentators note that instead of asking God
to lighten his burden, Moses should have asked

463.text:
God for the strength to bear it. Perhaps this
was another reason why he was not allowed

471.text:
In conclusion, both sides are right. Granted,
Moses could not physically do it all himself,

478.text:
but he should have increased personal interaction
with the common people. Delegating some authority

483.text:
is good, but this was the wrong time to do
it in such a massive, formal way. This leaves

489.text:
open the questions: When is the right time
and what is the proper balance?
